summary: This is an ex parte declaration by an FBI Special Agent in support of the government's response to a motion to quash grand jury subpoenas for computers belonging to Jeffrey Epstein. The declaration details the FBI's investigation into Epstein's solicitation of minors for prostitution, the removal of computers from his home prior to a search warrant, and the potential evidence they contain, including message logs, photographs, and financial records related to alleged crimes.

persons.name: Jeffrey Epstein
persons.context: The central subject of the FBI and grand jury investigation for solicitation of minors for prostitution, lewd conduct, and potential financial crimes. The declaration details evidence of his activities and attempts to hide evidence.

persons.name: Ghislaine Maxwell
persons.context: Described as Epstein's associate who helped arrange and pay for travel for a young woman and her siblings for photography sessions, and was confronted about missing photographs.

persons.name: Janusz Banasiak
persons.role: Property manager for Jeffrey Epstein's Palm Beach home
persons.context: Interviewed by the FBI agent. He stated he did not remove computers from Epstein's home and identified others who did.

persons.name: Paul Lavery
persons.context: Identified as the private investigator who took computer equipment from Epstein's home. He was subpoenaed and interviewed, stating he received the computers from a woman believed to be Sarah Kellen and later delivered them to William Riley.

persons.name: William Riley
persons.role: Private investigator, principal of Riley Kiraly firm
persons.context: The person to whom Paul Lavery delivered the computers from Epstein's home. Grand jury subpoenas were served on him and his firm.

persons.name: Sarah Kellen
persons.context: Referred to as 'S.K.' and identified as a personal assistant to Epstein. She is considered a target of the investigation and was implicated in the removal of computers.

persons.name: Roy Black
persons.context: Mentioned to clarify that the investigation firm Riley Kiraly does not work exclusively for him or any other lawyer.

connections.description: Maxwell is described as Epstein's associate who helped arrange travel and payments for photography sessions involving young women and their siblings.
Kellen is identified as a personal assistant to Epstein. She is implicated in the removal of computers from his home prior to a search warrant.
Banasiak was the property manager for Epstein's Palm Beach home at the time of the search warrant execution.
Lavery, a private investigator, delivered computers taken from Epstein's home to William Riley, another private investigator.
According to Lavery's interview, a woman he believed was Sarah Kellen gave him the computer equipment from Epstein's home.

events.title: Execution of state search warrant at Epstein's Palm Beach home
events.description: The Palm Beach Police Department executed a search warrant at Jeffrey Epstein's residence, 358 El Brillo Way. Investigators observed disconnected surveillance cables where computer equipment appeared to have been removed.

events.title: Message log evidence of contact with underage female
events.description: An electronic message log documented a call from Epstein's assistant regarding the availability of an identified underage female to 'work'. Phone records show contact between the assistant and the female minutes before.

events.title: FBI opens investigation into Epstein
events.description: The FBI opened a case file in July 2006 after being contacted by a Palm Beach detective regarding Epstein's solicitation of minors for prostitution and lewd conduct.

events.title: FBI agent signs declaration in support of subpoena response
events.description: An FBI Special Agent signs this ex parte declaration detailing the investigation and rationale for needing computers subpoenaed by the grand jury.

events.title: Removal of computers from Epstein's home
events.description: Computers were removed from Jeffrey Epstein's Palm Beach home by Sarah Kellen and private investigator Paul Lavery, prior to the execution of a search warrant.

locations: 358 El Brillo Way, Palm Beach, Florida (Jeffrey Epstein's residence)
New Mexico (location of one of Epstein's homes/ranch)
Miami, Florida (location of Riley Kiraly offices)
keyFacts: The FBI agent believes computers were purposely removed from Jeffrey Epstein's home in anticipation of the October 2005 search warrant execution.
Evidence includes electronic message logs recovered from trash at Epstein's home showing appointments and contact with an underage female, suggesting the computers could contain more such evidence.

The investigation uncovered that Epstein and Ghislaine Maxwell arranged and paid for a young woman and her minor siblings to travel for nude 'artistic' photography sessions, and that seven photographs from these sessions went missing.

The grand jury is investigating potential financial crimes including promotion money laundering and unlawful money transmitting, involving large transfers between Epstein's bank accounts and an entity (JEGE, Inc.) created to hold his aircraft.
Private investigator Paul Lavery admitted to taking computers from Epstein's home (given to him by a woman believed to be Sarah Kellen) and delivering them to another investigator, William Riley.
